awd_titl_txt: Tenth Annual Graduate Student Mini-Conference in Computational Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students in the Tenth Annual Graduate Student Mini-Conference in Computational Mathematics, held at Auburn University on April 25-27, 2020. This two-day conference centers on recent advances in the theory and numerical approximation of partial differential equation models with applications in the areas such as materials science, optics, turbulence, hydrology, biomedical flows, and climate systems. Established in 2009, the conference aims to provide graduate students with a timely opportunity to present their research, exchange ideas, and build their collaborative networks in a setting that is supportive yet similar to that of a larger conference. The conference organizers are committed to supporting the participation of graduate students, early career researchers, and researchers from underrepresented groups.

Many important applications in science and engineering are modeled by partial differential equations, and there has been an increasing need for accurate and robust numerical methods for such models. Conference topics include robust and efficient numerical simulations, reduced order models, optimization, uncertainty quantification, and data assimilation. The conference organizers estimate an attendance of around 45 participants, including two plenary speakers, thirty graduate students, and their research advisors. The student speakers will be selected from attendees based on their curriculum vitae and recommendation by their advisors about their research achievements.
The conference website is http://www.auburn.edu/cosam/departments/math/compconference/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
On December 10, 2022, 16 graduate students from Auburn University, University of Alabama at Birmingham, University of Florida, Florida State University, Georgia State, Clemson University, University of South Carolina, and Missouri Institute of Science & Technology, most of them accompanied by their faculty advisors, presented their work at the Tenth Graduate Student Miniconference in Computational Mathematics at Auburn University. We managed to recruit a  relatively diverse pool of graduate student speakers (many international students, 5 women, 2 hispanic students) with a range of interests within computational mathematics, and were able to involve two new local universities, University of Alabama at Birmingham and Georgia State. The estimated attendance was between 30 and 40 people. 

Thematically, the conference centered on differential equation models for physical systems, and the development and numerical analysis of computational tools for their efficient simulation and for parameter- and state estimation. Machine learning featured prominently in this conference, with talks on the use of computational statistics tools for classification, or for speeding up numerical simulations, as well as on the novel improvements of neural network approximations in inifinite dimensions. Many talks dealt with innovations in computational fluid dynamics, including novel timestepping and splitting schemes, reduced order models for fluid-structure interactions, and the development of numerical schemes in the presence of limited regularity or cracks. Relatedly, spectral properties of Sturm Liouville systems with low regularity were discussed, as well as those of materials related to edge states in mechanical systems arising in materials science. Another prominent theme was the formulation and analysis of mathematical models of novel mechanical and biological systems, such as motion-induced energy generation or algal growth on porous lattice structures, and the incorporation of experiments for complementing the modeling/simulation process, e.g. data assimilation in parabolic systems, or the effect of wedge shape on the flight stability of wedge projectiles. The talks were arranged in a single session, allowing students to gain exposure to a variety of research areas in computational mathematics. 

This mini-conference provided a unique opportunity for graduate student participants to practice giving a scientific talk before an audience of peers and faculty within a setting that is more informal than that of a regular conference. We kept strict time limits, and many students who had not had much practice giving 15 minute talks realized the importance of time-management, finding the correct points to emphasize, and giving short insightful explanations. There were many discussions following the talks, both on their scientific content and their form.

The conference allowed plenty of time for students and faculty to network and discuss topics offline. There were three coffee breaks and a lunch break so that attendants could easily interact, catch up with old colleagues, or meet new ones.
